description: slap +â€Ž dash. First attested in the late 17th century, meaning "careless".

adjectives.description: slapdash (comparative more slapdash, superlative most slapdash)

entries.meaning: Produced or carried out hastily; haphazard; careless.
examples: When you're in the front entrance, get a feel for what's going on. Tours are never timed to coincide with breaks but if there are any children milling about, see what they're up to. If they're on a dutiful errand, for example delivering registers, the school probably encourages a responsible attitude. If they're play-fighting in the corridor without consequence, it tells a less impressive story and could mean a slapdash approach to discipline.

adverbs.description: slapdash (comparative more slapdash, superlative most slapdash)

entries.meaning: In a hasty or careless manner.

examples: Van Eyck signed his portrait of the Arnolfinis slapdash in the center of the painting.

entries.meaning: With a slap; all at once; slap.

verbs.description: slapdash (third-person singular simple present slapdashes, present participle slapdashing, simple past and past participle slapdashed)

entries.meaning: (colloquial) To apply, or apply something to, in a hasty, careless, or rough manner; to roughcast.
examples: to slapdash mortar or paint on a wall
